results.title: The Columbia River
results.brief_description: A survey of the Columbia River System, the world’s largest single source of hydroelectric power. Shows the multi-purpose dams, discusses US-Canadian agreements for further development, and explains the value of the waterway in irrigation, navigation and flood control.

results.brief_description: Shows the natural wonders of Yellowstone National Park during the winter months when tourists are gone and the hot water springs and mud-baths steam and bubble.

results.title: The Color of man
results.creator_credit: Robert Carl Cohen and University of California, Los Angeles
results.brief_description: Explains the reason for variation in skin color of people of the different nationalities. The film describes how in prehistoric times humans living near the equator could not protect themselves from the direct ultra-violent rays of the sun, and did not survive unless they developed a protective pigment in their skin known as melanin. Similarly those living away from the direct ultra-violet developed a fair skin which permitted the rays to penetrate, for a certain amount of ultra-violet light is essential for life. Narrated by Robert Doubleday.

results.title: Color keying in art and living
results.brief_description: An analysis of color relationships. Considers the following: nature of light rays, the spectrum and primary colors; secondary colors and pigment primaries; light reflection by pigments; color keying; complimentary colors; the color wheel; how complimentary colors intensify one another; how color may be used to “echo” itself.

results.title: Color her sunshine
results.creator_credit: Doris Lawrence, National Educational Television and WCET
results.brief_description: The story of Mary who was born with Down’s syndrome. Down’s syndrome children respond to individual love and attention, and are capable of taking care of themselves as they grow into adulthood. Mary is seen doing simple tasks in a sheltered workshop and participating in recreational activities.

results.title: Color categorising behaviour of rhesus monkeys
results.brief_description: This psychological study is part of a research project on brain disorders. For over a year, adult male and female Rhesus monkeys and a baby monkey were trained and taught to sort various objects according to their size, color and shape. Such experiments and their results are of primary interest to psychology students.

results.title: Color and pigment in art
results.brief_description: Demonstrates by use of a glass prism that white light is actually a combination of several colors, which can be reproduced by pigments. Shows how the three primary colors can be mixed to make secondary colors and, in turn, intermediate colors. A color solid shows the three dimensions of color - hue, value and intensity, and examples illustrate how combinations of colors can create pleasing effects and different moods and feelings.
results.description: Demonstrates by use of a glass prism that white light is actually a combination of several colors, which can be reproduced by pigments. results.title: The Colour of life
results.creator_credit: J.V. Durden, Guy Glover and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description: This film probes the perennial miracle of the growth of a seedling, the seasonal upsurge of life in a forest giant, and the mysterious alchemy of a single leaf. Presented in magnified dimension through time-lapse photography and animated diagrams, a maple leaf and segments of a tree serve to illustrate the physiological processes that go on in all plants.
results.creator_credit_for_label: J.V. Durden, Guy Glover and National Film Board of Canada

results.title: The Colonies look ahead
results.creator_credit: John Howe, Ronald Dick and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description:
Episode number 12 of Series “The Commonwealth of Nations”.
A film survey of economic development, education and race relations in various British colonial territories. Progress in representative colonies, such as Kenya, is assessed on the basis of their ability to manage their own affairs and to achieve self-government. Narrated by Edgar McInnis.
